text:
Thank you Chris, that's some very helpful feedback. Especially to be wary of a "top down" approach, perhaps I can temper some of the proposal-idealism by calling a few associations and hearting what their pain points are. I already had one reach out to me (part of what started this), but I don't think my understanding of the pain point is quite complete.

I'm still wondering if there is an opportunity for some kind of hackathon, because these are already operating as volunteer organizations. Since many elements of digital transformation are one-time, it could be a good fit for the time-bound nature of competitions, as long as the incentive structures are developed correctly.

elements.text:

text: I agree with <@UDQBTJ211>, and would add that when you start replacing the current workflows you should probably build up the new systems on top of something quite mundane (say, Google Sheets) with a thin layer of automation rather than starting with loads of large scale software development.

elements.text: , and would add that when you start replacing the current workflows you should probably build up the new systems on top of something quite mundane (say, Google Sheets) with a thin layer of automation rather than starting with loads of large scale software development.

text:
The longest lasting part of tech is the data and the API. Languages change, codebases change, but data and APIs live forever. My two cents, use the grant to make an extendable API to expose all necessary data and actions. Once that's up, then you can definitely make micro-grants to let people use the API to solve their problems.

To make something particularly long lasting, focus on doing everything with standards rather than particular tech, like HTTP, REST, JSON, and SQL.

elements.text:
The longest lasting part of tech is the data and the API. Languages change, codebases change, but data and APIs live forever. My two cents, use the grant to make an extendable API to expose all necessary data and actions. Once that's up, then you can definitely make micro-grants to let people use the API to solve their problems.

To make something particularly long lasting, focus on doing everything with standards rather than particular tech, like HTTP, REST, JSON, and SQL.

text:
Thank you for the feedback Jack and tyler. The way I'm seeing it evolve now is perhaps taking an iterative approach to do just that. Round one will be very mundane using off-the-shelf solutions, round two will be focused more on the data and how it interacts, and round three could become more of the focused API creation using the boringest languages. But if the customers are really happy with just round one, I'll leave it open to the possibility of stopping the project there.

I did something similar with my last project where we started with a simple jotform survey, built a more advanced version in bubble, and then created the opportunity for a custom app, But ultimately the market told us that wasn't needed.
